Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Small: Cell Phone-Based Activity Tracking for Telehealth

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
SHB: Small: Cell Phone-Based Activity Monitoring for Telehealth

Abstract

Contemporary smart cell phones contain a tri-axial accelerometer, which makes it possible to measure the acceleration of a smart phone user in all three spatial dimensions. Modern data mining methods permit the construction of an activity recognition classifier from this acceleration data, so that a user's physical activity (e.g., walking, jogging, standing, etc.) can be automatically inferred from the accelerometer values. This research project will build an activity recognition system that can be deployed as a downloadable cell phone application. Users will then be able to access a description of their activities via a web interface and can use this information to monitor and change their behavior. Thus this research can be used to address the many health-related problems that result from physical inactivity. It can also assist with other health-related problem, such as falling in the elderly, by detecting falls and providing automatic notification to caregivers. The data generated via the cell phone activity recognition system will also enable large scale epidemiological studies of activity levels and health that, due to prohibitive costs, were not previously possible.

Building a successful activity recognition system will require addressing many technical challenges. This research will require improved feature construction methods for transforming time-series data into representations suitable for example-oriented classification algorithms. It will also require the evaluation of alternate architectures for performing wide-scale real-time data mining, in order to determine how much of the activity recognition work should be performed on the client (i.e., smart phone) versus a centralized server. The adequacy of smart cell phones for performing reliable activity recognition will also be evaluated given the many constraints (e.g., limited battery life) imposed by these devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project demonstrated that smartphones are capable of identifying basic everyday activities and subsequently showed that smartphones paired with a smartwatch are capable of identifying a wider range of activities (including hand-based activities and eating and drinking activities) with even higher accuracy.  One  key research result of this study is that personalized models, built from activity data from the intended user, can outperform more general impersonal models, even with very limited quantities of labeled data (e.g., one minute of data per activity).  Our activity recognition models utilized accelerometer and gyroscope data from the smartwatch and smartphone; the project results show that the accelerometer generally outperforms the gyroscope and the smartwatch sensors generally outperform the smartphone sensors. Overall, the smartwatch accelerometer sensor yields the best results although improved results can be achieved by fusing all of the sensor data.

A smartphone-based system called Actitracker was built and made available for use by the general public. This system provided results to the user via a web-based interface and a phone-based interface. The Actitracker app also guided the user through a self-training phase and personalized models were constructed dynamically once sufficient data were accumulated. This system demonstrated that commercial smartphone are capable of providing good activity recognition results for basic activities.

The technology underlying this project was applied to other health related problems and work is currently ongoing to use it to identify ADHD behavior in children. The same underlying activity recognition was utilized to distinguish normal gait from abnormal gait, with modest results. The methods underlying this project were also applied to identify users based on the way they moved and achieved outstanding results (this work in gait-based biometrics was not part of this project but would not have been possible without the methods we developed for activity recognition).

This project provided educational and research opportunities to dozens of undergraduate students and a half-dozen graduate students. In particular, many undergraduate students worked on this project for several years, were deeply involved in the research, and were co-authors on research papers published in international conferences. The participation in this project enabled these students to acquire dozens of student research grants from our university and to work extensively on the project over the summer. Students acquired skills strongly desired by industry, including mobile programming, web programming, and software engineering skills.  Women are a significantly underrepresented group in Computer Science and this project gave many young women exposure to research and assisted several in acquiring Clare Boothe Luce full-tuition scholarships.
